fields.summary: Empty state for new chats via search bar

issuetype.description: Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

content.text: As a user, I want to see a clean view when I start a conversation through the search bar,  so that I can have a less cluttered interface.
We currently have two methods for starting conversations: one using the search bar and another using a newly added button (

When starting a conversation through the search bar, if no existing conversation with the selected contact is found, the contact's avatar, name, and phone number are displayed in the main conversation area, positioned above the message input field and send button. However, when creating group conversations with multiple participants, this results in a cluttered view, showcasing one avatar, name, and phone number for each user, which can be visually overwhelming and confusing, as shown in the following image.
To enhance the user experience, we aim to synchronize both conversation creation methods, ensuring that the visual presentation and overall experience are cohesive.

Implementing an empty state similar to the one used in the new conversation creation method, accessible via the dedicated button for conversations initiated through the search bar, will allow us to remove redundant contact details, such as avatars, names and phone numbers, from the conversation view. This change will result in a cleaner, more consistent, and easier-to-read interface, especially for group conversations.
FR1. Start a new conversation from the header
The user selects one or more contacts in the header's search
If there‚Äôs no existing conversation with the selected contact(s), a placeholder image and text are displayed
The conversation header is also displayed when creating a new conversation with a single contact (not in ad-hoc groups)
By sending a message or choosing to create a named group (through the modal), the conversation becomes effective, and the placeholder is replaced by the conversation body
FR2. Existing conversation when adding people in the header
The user selects one or more contact in the header's search
If a prior conversation exists, it should be loaded in the main conversation area
If by adding or removing contacts, the conversation is considered new again, the placeholder mentioned in FR1 should be displayed
Ad-hoc groups can only be created as external-only or internal-only
After selecting an external contact, internal contacts appear disabled
After selecting an internal contact, external contacts and unsaved numbers appear disabled
When more than 1 internal contact is added, the existing buttons to video call (if allowed) or create a named group should be displayed in the header‚Äôs search bar
If only 1 internal contact is selected, a button to start a voice call is also displayed
The position of the placeholder (combination of image and text) is relative to the chat footer with a distance of about 20% the chat area‚Äôs height
This position is to be assessed and better defined during development through design follow-ups

fields.summary: Display sending status for internal conversations

issuetype.description: Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

content.text: As a user, I want to see the sending status when I send an internal conversation message, so that I can confirm if the message was successfully sent.

Users do not currently receive immediate feedback on the status of sent messages in internal conversations, including both 1:1 and group conversations. The absence of visual indicators can cause frustration during message failures or delays. A similar feature exists for SMS. This proposal suggests implementing visual indicators for sent messages and offering users the option to resend messages if they fail.
The following requirements apply only to conversations with directory (internal) contacts, either groups or 1:1.
As the user hits send on an internal message, immediately display the new message bubble with the status ‚ÄúSending‚Äù
The message input should be cleared
The status ‚ÄúSending‚Äù will prevail until we can guarantee that it was successfully sent, or it returns an error
While in the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status, the user can‚Äôt long-tap to access more options
Upon confirmation that the message was sent, the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status is replaced with the status ‚ÄúSent‚Äù
The ‚ÄúSent‚Äù status is only displayed in the latest message successfully sent by the user
It‚Äôs now possible to long-tap on a message to access all existing options
FR3. Internal message fails to be sent
If the message fails to be sent, the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status is replaced with the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status, along with the retry option
This ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status remains attached to each message that failed to be sent by the user
The user can delete or copy a message with the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status
The options to reply or pin shouldn‚Äôt be displayed on a message with the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status
If the latest message in a conversation is the one that failed, the message ‚ÄúMessage failed to send‚Äù should be displayed as the preview of that conversation on the messages list
FR4. Retry sending the message on fail
When the message is in the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status, a retry button is displayed along with it (‚ÄúTap to retry‚Äù)
When the user taps on this retry option:
The message returns to the bottom of the chat (position of the latest sent message)
The message now displays the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status, and bears the same limitations as on FR1
The timestamp updates to correspond with the new attempt
Will follow the success or fail scenarios described in FR2 and FR3
Each message status bears a different icon, according to the assets provided
Message statuses are displayed under the sent message bubble, aligned to the right of the bubble‚Äôs body (excluding the tip affordance)
Message status updates as soon as we can get confirmation of its success or failure
The retry flow (getting the message back to the bottom of the chat with the sending status), should occur no later than 300ms after the user taps on the retry option.
Save an event on Google Analytics with the name: ‚Äúim_message_failed_retry‚Äù to count the number of times users tap on the inline error and retry to send.

fields.summary: Implement optimistic message sending with status display in internal chats

issuetype.description: Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

content.text: As a user, when I send a message in an internal chat, I want to see its status immediately so that I understand whether it was sent successfully and experience a more responsive interface.

Messages currently appear in the conversation only after receiving confirmation from the Messaging API. This can lead to delays, particularly on slow connections, making the system feel unresponsive. Additionally, users often have to retype their messages if they fail to send, which can result in frustration.

To enhance user experience, we plan to introduce optimistic message sending on our web/ desktop platform. When a message is sent in an internal conversation (including both 1:1 chats and group conversations) it will be displayed instantly in the conversation with a temporary sending state. This state will then be updated to either a sent state or a failed state (with an option to retry), depending on the response received from the backend.
The following requirements apply only to conversations with directory (internal) contacts, either groups or 1:1.
As the user hits send on an internal message, immediately display the new message bubble with the status ‚ÄúSending‚Äù
The send message button should no longer display a loading status when a message is being sent (both internal or SMS)
The status ‚ÄúSending‚Äù will prevail until we can guarantee that it was successfully sent, or it returns an error
While in the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status, the more options button (3-dots) shouldn‚Äôt be displayed
Upon confirmation that it was sent, the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status is replaced with the status ‚ÄúSent‚Äù
The ‚ÄúSent‚Äù status is only displayed in the latest message successfully sent by the user
The more options button (3-dots) is now displayed when hovering over the message
FR3. Internal message fails to be sent
If the message fails to be sent, the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status is replaced with the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status, along with the retry option
This ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status remains attached to each message that failed to be sent by the user
The user can delete a message with the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status
The options to reply, edit, or pin shouldn‚Äôt be displayed on the options of a message with the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status
FR4. Retry sending the message on fail
When the message is in the ‚ÄúFailed to send‚Äù status, a retry button is displayed along with it (‚ÄúClick to retry‚Äù)
When the user taps on this retry option:
The message returns to the bottom of the chat (position of the latest sent message)
The message now displays the ‚ÄúSending‚Äù status, and bears the same limitations as on FR1
The timestamp updates to correspond with the new attempt
Will follow the success or failure scenarios described in FR2 and FR3
Each message status bears a different icon, according to the assets provided
Message statuses are displayed under the sent message bubble, aligned to the right of the bubble‚Äôs body (excluding the tip affordance)
Message status updates as soon as we can get confirmation of its success or failure
The retry flow (getting the message back to the bottom of the chat with the sending status), should occur no later than 300ms after the user taps on the retry option.
Save an event on Google Analytics with the name: ‚Äúim_message_failed_retry‚Äù to count the number of times users tap on the inline error and retry to send.

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

content.text: Currently, our polling mechanism attempts to poll the same number of conversations that are currently loaded. This becomes problematic when users have more than 100 conversations loaded:
It doesn‚Äôt provide additional value since we only care about the latest changes, and the polling request is ordered by latest message.
Messaging API/Scylla will throw when fetching more the 100 conversations at once.
To optimize polling, we should restrict the limit to
, which aligns with the default load behavior.
Conversation polling should always use 30 as the limit, regardless of how many are currently loaded.
Load fewer than 30 conversations and verify polling handles them correctly.
Load more than 30 (e.g., 100+) and confirm only 30 are polled.
Confirm that polling results still reflect the most recent conversation updates.

fields.summary: Adjust incoming call notification when the user is on a call

issuetype.description: Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

content.text: As a user on an active call, I want a brief, non-intrusive audio alert for incoming calls, so that I can be notified without disrupting my conversation.

Users currently experience a poor notification experience during active calls due to competing audio sources. The standard continuous ringtone disrupts ongoing conversations. The goal is to enhance the incoming call notification for users already on a call.
When a user is on an "On call" state (audio or video call) and receives a new audio call:
The incoming call should play the provided audio instead of the standard ringtone.

While ringing, the audio will play in 10-second intervals, until it is answered, declined, or the caller hangs up (e.g. audio plays once, wait 10 seconds, then play again. This pattern is repeated until the call stops ringing).
The user should receive a visual notification of the incoming call (UI popup remains unchanged).
When a user is not in an ‚ÄúOn call‚Äù, or ‚ÄúDo not disturb‚Äù state, the incoming call should use the standard continuous ringtone.
This behavior should remain consistent across desktop and web platforms.

fields.summary: Implement reactive internal and external contact update handling

issuetype.description: Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

content.text: As a user, I want the updates to be reflected in real-time when I edit or delete a contact, so that I have the most current information.

Currently, updates to both internal and external contacts in the B-Hive Portal are not reflected in real-time across the app. Users must manually refresh or navigate to see updates. The backend will be updated to send real-time events when internal contacts are modified and deleted, allowing the frontend to receive updated information immediately.
, the updates should be immediately reflected, historically and going forward throughout the app, in the following interactions:
1:1 conversations (header, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
Named group conversation (members list, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
New conversation creation (in the unnamed section)
Softphone interface (receiving and making calls, including adding or transferring calls)
Contacts list (favorites and contacts, in the unnamed section)
1:1 conversations (header, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
Ad-hoc group conversation (header, members list, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
Contacts list (favorites and contacts, in the ‚ÄúContacts‚Äù section)
, the updates should be immediately reflected, historically and going forward throughout the app, in the following interactions:
1:1 conversations (header, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
Named group conversation (messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
1:1 conversations (header, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)
Ad-hoc group conversation (header, members list, messages bubble, system messages, mentions)

There is an issue reported by a client regarding voicemail sender names. When all users share the same CLID on their SIP accounts, the voicemail displays the name of the first user alphabetically in the location. Since the voicemail system does not have a personId in the endpoints, Android has always relied on the phone number for matching.

At the moment, we are simply displaying the information provided by the backend without performing any additional matching. We have already created an investigation ticket to look into the current logic for displaying sender names across all platforms and to determine what changes are needed to correctly display the sender name in voicemails.
Users are able to easily locate new or existing contacts, through the following options:
Messages tab (creating a new conversation or adding members to a named group conversation)
Video tab (creating a new meeting, in the invite users section)
Contacts tab (in via search or scrolling to the contact by name, in the unnamed section)
Contacts tab (via search or scrolling to the contact by name, in the "My contacts" section)

issuetype.description: Created by JIRA Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

content.text: Introduce user-selectable noise cancellation in the web video app using Twilio‚Äôs Krisp integration. This should reduce background noise for participants without degrading voice quality, and be configurable per user.
Provide a toggle/control for noise cancellation in the web client.
Apply Krisp noise suppression during live calls when enabled.
Ensure default behavior aligns with product decision (e.g., on by default unless specified).
Persist user preference within the browser;
To the current ‚ÄúAudio settings‚Äù a new switch is added ‚ÄúSuppress background noise‚Äù, under the microphone settings
This option is on by default
This option is available both on the lobby screen and the ongoing meeting
On unsupported browsers (e.g., Safari/iOS), this option is not be displayed
The noise cancellation preference persists per user across sessions on the same browser
FR2. Modal layout updates (lobby and meeting)
The order of the Speakers and Microphone settings has changed
Update the title of this modal to ‚ÄúAudio & video settings‚Äù
Participants experience noticeably reduced background noise on web.
No significant degradation in voice clarity or latency.
Clear UI affordance indicating current noise cancellation status.
Users can enable/disable noise cancellation in-call on supported browsers.
On unsupported browsers (e.g., Safari/iOS), the settings should not display the noise cancellation option.
Setting takes effect without requiring the user to rejoin the call.
Noise cancellation preference should persist per user across sessions on the same browser.
No regression in call setup success rate (test multiple browsers, including Safari), CPU usage within acceptable thresholds for typical hardware, and no significant added latency.
Analytics/telemetry records when noise cancellation is enabled/disabled (Google analytics).

fields.summary: [Messaging API] Cap conversations limit fetch to 100

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

content.text: Currently, when the backend receives a request for more than 100 conversations, ScyllaDB throws an error. While the controller currently rejects requests with a limit higher than 300, this threshold is too high.
If a request asks for >100 conversations, the backend should automatically cap it to 100 instead of throwing an error or rejecting.
This ensures backward compatibility, since we don‚Äôt want to set the limit constraint on the endpoint directly (to avoid breaking legacy clients).
Any request with limit > 100 is automatically reduced to 100.
Requests with limit <= 100 continue to behave normally.
Requests with no limit parameter keep the current default behavior.
ScyllaDB query should never try fetching more than 100 conversations.
Implement logic in the controller/service layer to cap limit at 100 before making the DB call.
Do not return an error for limits over 100, apply the cap silently.
Update logging to indicate when capping is applied (optional debug logging).
Fetch with limit = 50 ‚Üí returns up to 50.
Fetch with limit = 100 ‚Üí returns up to 100.
Fetch with limit = 200 ‚Üí returns up to 100 (no error).
Fetch with limit = 1000 ‚Üí returns up to 100 (no error).
Confirm no Scylla errors are thrown at high request limits.
The error is not reproducible in labs due to different scylladb restrictions.

content.text: A flicker appears on the user's caller ID after receiving a call on Android.

It could probably be related to the fact that permission to access contacts was only given after the call had already arrived.
